docs.lead_paragraph: More than two weeks after a contract expired, union workers remain locked out, leaving management to handle repairs and maintenance.

headline.seo: Con Ed Managers Splice Cables, or Hold Flashlights
headline.main: At Con Ed, the Managers Are Tasked With Repairs
headline.print_headline: At Con Ed, the Managers Are Tasked With Repairs

docs.abstract: Consolidated Edison has deployed 5,000 of its managers to handle repairs and maintenance as the lockout of its unionized utility workers continues.
docs.snippet: More than two weeks after a contract expired, union workers remain locked out, leaving management to handle repairs and maintenance.

docs.lead_paragraph: Property taxes help cover health costs for the uninsured, a burden on residents that Gov. Rick Perry’s rejection of Medicaid expansion would maintain.

headline.seo: Texas Counties Fear Cost of Medicaid Rebuff
headline.main: Texas Counties Fear Residents Will Pay the Price of Perry’s Medicaid Rebuff
headline.print_headline: Texas Counties Fear Residents Will Pay the Price of Perry’s Medicaid Rebuff

docs.abstract: Texas Gov Rick Perry's decision to refuse federal health care law provisions expanding Medicaid and creating a state insurance exchange will be felt in the state's counties; some local leaders say decision will hurt county taxpayers, whose property taxes help cover health costs for the uninsured.
docs.snippet: Property taxes help cover health costs for the uninsured, a burden on residents that Gov. Rick Perry’s rejection of Medicaid expansion would maintain.

docs.lead_paragraph: A column by Bill Keller on Monday referred incorrectly to one consequence of the 2010 health care law. While it is estimated to provide coverage to 30 million Americans who are currently uninsured, the estimate includes both an expansion of Medicaid and additional enrollment in private insurance plans, not only the latter.

docs.lead_paragraph: American businesses that wait too long to investigate opportunities in Egypt, Libya and newly liberalized nations could be left behind, some argue.

headline.seo: After the Arab Spring, a Rush to Do Business in the Middle East
headline.main: A Rush to Do Business in the Middle East

docs.abstract: Political and economic changes in the Middle East more than a year after the Arab Spring have closed some doors and opened others for business people willing to tolerate risk; some analysts say American businesses that wait too long to investigate opportunities in Egypt, Libya and newly liberalized nations could be left behind.
docs.snippet: American businesses that wait too long to investigate opportunities in Egypt, Libya and newly liberalized nations could be left behind, some argue.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some are calling on fertility doctors to rely less on high doses of hormones to avoid serious complications, even if it means lower rates of success.

headline.seo: High Doses of Hormones Add to IVF Complications
headline.main: High Doses of Hormones Faulted in Fertility Care
headline.print_headline: High Doses of Hormones Faulted in Fertility Care

docs.abstract: Critics are calling on doctors to rely less on high doses of hormones in fertility treatments, to avoid serious complications such as ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome, even if it means lower pregnancy rates; fertility clinics in Europe and Japan have turned to a safer, low-dose form of in vitro fertilization, shift that has been resisted in the United States.
docs.snippet: Some are calling on fertility doctors to rely less on high doses of hormones to avoid serious complications, even if it means lower rates of success.

docs.lead_paragraph: Watching Robin Roberts tear up in front of millions of viewers on ''Good Morning America'' last month, I cried, too. With equal measures of courage and fear, Ms. Roberts, an anchor of the show and a breast cancer survivor, explained that the life-saving treatment she received five years ago was responsible for a new diagnosis, this time myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), a rare blood and bone marrow disease once called preleukemia.

headline.main: Essay: New Cancer Threat Lurks Long After Cure

docs.abstract: Secondary cancers, those caused by radiation treatment and chemotherapy, now make up the sixth-most-common group of malignancies; trend means that more people than ever are surviving their original cancers only to be haunted by the prospect of new diagnoses later. Photo (M)1
